timeline.summary: An email was sent from an individual attending Balmoral Summer Camp to Ghislaine Maxwell on August 16, 2001. The sender expresses exhaustion from camp activities and requests information about Maxwell’s activities in Los Angeles. The sender also indicates availability for travel from August 25th to September 2nd, seeking “fun people” and a “hot and sunny” destination.

On October 18, 2007, Jay Lefkowitz discussed the change of plea date for Mr. Epstein with Alex Acosta and Florida counsel. The plea was initially scheduled for a different date but was moved to November 20th due to availability concerns. Lefkowitz sought confirmation that this date change wouldn’t impact Epstein’s sentence commencement. Acosta had previously advised against dictating a schedule to the state.

On June 11, 2008, emails were exchanged regarding a phone call to discuss Epstein. Multiple individuals expressed availability for a call on Friday, June 13, 2008, at 10:00 AM Eastern Time (US & Canada), with options for times between 10:00 AM and 11:00 AM, and after 11:00 AM. The emails involved individuals with redacted names and email addresses.

On June 11, 2008, emails were exchanged regarding a phone call with Jeffrey Epstein. The call was scheduled for Friday, June 13, 2008, from 10:00 AM to 10:30 AM (GMT-05:00) Eastern Time, to be conducted by phone. Multiple individuals expressed availability for the call, including [REDACTED], [REDACTED], and [REDACTED]. The call was marked as X-PERSONAL priority.

On June 13, 2008, at 10:00 AM - 10:30 AM (GMT-05:00), a call was scheduled between individuals associated with USAFLS, ODAG, and SMO to discuss an “Epstein” matter. The call was to take place at an unspecified office location and could be conducted by phone. Participants included [REDACTED] and [REDACTED]. Correspondence leading up to the call occurred on June 11, 2008, with discussions regarding availability and a phone number (305) 961-9299.  Multiple individuals expressed availability for the call, with conflicting times noted.

On June 13, 2008, from 10:00 AM to 10:30 AM (GMT-05:00), there was a scheduled phone call, designated as "Epstein," involving multiple redacted individuals. The call was to be held at an unspecified office location and was categorized as X-PERSONAL. Multiple individuals expressed availability for the call, including those sending and receiving emails regarding the meeting. One individual, IM, requested a preferred phone number for participation.

On June 19, 2008, an email chain discusses Jeff Epstein with representatives from the USAFLS and FBI. One individual (Assistant U.S. Attorney) expresses doubt about Roy Black calling again and confirms a deadline for a response. Another individual (Brad Edwards) proposes a meeting to share information and concerns regarding Epstein’s alleged misconduct, suggesting availability between July 23-25. Jason Richards expresses concern about Epstein as an attorney. All communications are flagged as privileged and confidential.

This redaction analysis document (EFTA00037161.pdf) contains a single redaction. The redacted document is an email exchange between Adam Castellani and Sheri, discussing scheduling sessions with a female therapist at Portman Square. The email chain details availability options for July 2nd and July 5th, with potential sessions planned for September as well. Contact information for Adam Castellani (adam.castellani@citi.com) and Yahoo Finance are also included.

The document contains email exchanges between Adam Castellani and [REDACTED] regarding scheduling therapy sessions with Dr. Sheri. Castellani was initially inquiring about availability and received a response from [REDACTED] offering sessions on July 2nd or July 5th at Portman Square. The emails also include contact information for Adam Castellani (adam.castellani@citi.com) and a Yahoo Finance watchlist.

A hearing was held with Judge Marra regarding an agreement. Judge Marra ordered the agreement’s availability to plaintiffs and their counsel under a protective order, extending to any identified victims and their attorneys if they agree to the order. The plaintiffs can directly address further disclosure with Mr. Epstein in their civil suits. The sender will provide the court order and signed protective order to Jay and Roy Black upon receipt.

A person (identified as “_”) is requesting accommodation in New York City from October 15th to 21st. They also inquire about the availability of team Epstein in Paris this weekend. The email includes contact information and a disclaimer regarding the confidential nature of the message.

On December 10, 2018, an Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York contacted two individuals (“You guys”) requesting a conference call to discuss “a few items.” A response was received from an FBI agent (“N. (NY) (FBI)”) confirming availability and noting the urgency due to preparation for an upcoming event on December 12, 2018.

An email chain discusses an investigation related to the Jeffrey Epstein sex trafficking case and accusations in Miami Herald articles. Individuals are coordinating to add further investigations and confirm the availability of resources (specifically, a download - d/l) for the case. A link to the Miami Herald article is included.

An email exchange occurred between multiple individuals regarding updates related to the Epstein matter. One individual was traveling back and suggested a meeting for Monday. Another individual requested a morning meeting to discuss a trip and wanted to hear more about the situation. A third individual inquired about the status of the group's availability.

Email exchanges between individuals at USANYS and a contractor regarding a meeting about Epstein. Proposed meeting times discussed, including 1:30 PM, 10:00 AM, noon, and 5:30 PM, due to scheduling conflicts related to interviews and availability of senior personnel (“brass”). A 30-minute meeting was initially requested.

On March 1, 2019, the Public Corruption Unit of the U.S. Attorney’s Office for the Southern District of New York contacted individuals regarding an investigation related to Jeffrey Epstein. One individual responded with availability for a call at 1:30 PM. Another individual, a Deputy Chief, initiated the contact, introducing the unit and inquiring about a call time the following day or Monday. The email chain includes redacted names and email addresses.

An email thread discusses a request for a brief meeting (5-10 minutes) to discuss updates related to Jeffrey Epstein. The initial email proposes 11:30 AM, while a follow-up suggests availability until noon. The sender is an Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York.

The initial request for the proffer was made on April 3, 2019, with a proposed meeting time of Friday at 11:00 AM at the client’s office.  Alex Conlon requests information about the client's current name and any phone numbers associated with her and/or Jeffrey Epstein. The other parties involved in the meeting are Alex Hess and Jenna Dabbs. A follow-up email offered availability on Thursday and Friday, and confirmed the intention to provide a standard proffer agreement. The entire communication involves redactions of sensitive information.

An Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York sent an email requesting a brief meeting (5-10 minutes) to discuss “quick Epstein updates.” The email was sent on April 3, 2019, and offered availability until noon that day.

Multiple individuals ([REDACTED]) were discussing a person named "Epstein." One individual confirmed that a previous contact was the same person, while another expressed availability to review a format question and asked for a memo regarding updates and next steps related to a meeting with Brad Weinshiemer.  A travel schedule was also mentioned, with one individual unable to complete a task due to travel.

An individual (Assistant U.S. Attorney) is attempting to contact a woman identified as “her” (likely a subject of interest) who has been unreachable. Communication has been relayed through multiple individuals, including [REDACTED], Stan, and Sid Garcia’s office.  The primary goal is to schedule a call for “her” within the coming week, preferably Wednesday, Tuesday, or Thursday.  Concerns are being expressed about time constraints and the need to finalize travel plans.  Updates are being sought from those involved regarding “her” availability and contact information.

legal system in late June 2019. Key themes include: *   **New York Attorney General Actions:** Investigations into Bitfinex, Insys Pharmaceuticals kickbacks, and other state legal actions. *   **Second Circuit Court Cases:** Decisions regarding Lehman Brothers, Goldman Sachs, and other cases before the Second Circuit Court of Appeals. *   **Bankruptcy Proceedings:** Developments in cases like BlueHippo Funding and Sungard Availability Services. *   **SEC Enforcement:** Ongoing scrutiny of cryptocurrency markets and related regulatory actions. *   **Various Litigation:** Disputes related to intellectual property (Lionbridge, TransPerfect), real estate (chess builders), employment (CKR Law), benefits, and other areas (e.g., SiriusXM, Express Scripts, Total Wine & More). *   **Supreme Court Decisions:** A ruling on Tennessee liquor license requirements and a clarification regarding “Auer deference.” *   **Firm News & Recognition:** Updates on firms like O’Melveny & Myers winning “best to work for” titles and other achievements. *   **Job Postings:** Several job listings from law firms seeking attorneys across various practice areas. The document includes news about specific legal battles, regulatory actions, and firm activities.

Several individuals discussed scheduling a meeting to discuss a forfeiture question related to a property involved in the Jeffrey Epstein case. The proposed meeting times were between 1:00 PM and 2:00 PM, or 2:30 PM and 4:00 PM. Three individuals – [REDACTED], [REDACTED], and [REDACTED] – indicated availability at different times, with one agreeing to 3:30 PM. The discussion occurred via email and included references to a meeting with Judge Sullivan.

On July 10, 2019, a Chief Psychologist at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) notified [REDACTED] and [REDACTED] about Jared Epstein’s removal from psychiatric observation and the availability of notes regarding his situation. A POFU (Pending Order for Use of Force) was requested for tomorrow, July 11, 2019, due to a crisis. The communication referenced inmate EFTA00035269.

An Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York contacted Roberta Kaplan and others involved in the Epstein case regarding the Crime Victims' Rights Act (18 U.S.C. 3771(a)(4)). The Attorney offered to discuss with the victims (Kaplan, Dabbs, Elenowitz-Hess) the possibility of them being heard at a bail hearing and potentially submitting information for inclusion in a bail submission. The Attorney indicated their availability for a brief call to discuss this further, emphasizing that it was a voluntary offer and not a requirement. The email included a standard disclaimer regarding confidential information.

An Assistant U.S. Attorney in the Southern District of New York sent an email regarding the U.S. v. Epstein case (19 Cr. 490). The email discussed the Crime Victims’ Rights Act (18 U.S.C. 3771(a)(4)) and the victim’s right to be reasonably heard at bail hearings. The Attorney offered to discuss with the recipients whether the client wished to submit a statement or representation for inclusion in the bail submission, emphasizing it was voluntary. The Attorney proposed a brief call to discuss this further, noting their limited availability due to team travel.

v. Epstein case (19 Cr. 490). *   Reid Weingarten, a defense attorney, is coordinating with government counsel ([REDACTED]) and Judge Berman’s chambers. *   Discussions revolve around the government's bail memorandum and the defendant’s motion for bail. *   Attendees express availability for meetings on Monday morning, with a proposed agenda. *   The government provided an attached document (Government’s reply in support of its detention memo and in opposition to the defendant’s motion for bail) filed this afternoon.

v. Epstein (19 Cr. 490 (RMB)). *   There are multiple email exchanges discussing scheduling a meeting to discuss the case, particularly regarding a visit to Reid Weingarten following the hearing. *   The government expresses a willingness to speak with Weingarten on Monday morning, contingent on a general understanding of the client’s priorities. *   The government provided the bail memorandum and supporting exhibits to Judge Berman. *   There's a request to ensure all parties are kept informed via communication to account for varying team availability.

On July 16, 2019, Mark S. Cohen, representing Maxwell, contacted Christian Everdell and the U.S. Attorney’s office in the Southern District of New York regarding an SDNY investigation related to Jeffrey Epstein. Cohen requested a meeting at 5:00 PM to discuss the matter and inquired about allowing his team to bring phones into the building. Everdell responded, confirming availability for a meeting and asking about the feasibility of retaining phones, pending Cohen’s discussion with his client.

Christian Everdell contacted Mark S. Cohen and an Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding representation of Ms. Maxwell in an SDNY investigation (re: Epstein). Everdell requested a meeting that afternoon and inquired about access to the building for phones. The Assistant U.S. Attorney responded, confirming availability for a meeting and asking about the client’s prior communication.

Martin Weinberg inquired about the availability of the original documents related to the U.S. v. Epstein case (19 Cr. 490 (RMB)). Mike, an Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York, attached photographs and stated that pages 6 and 7 were blank and unphotographed.

On July 17, 2019, two attorneys reported complaints regarding the Epstein legal team occupying the SHU visiting room for extended periods. One individual was investigating these complaints and seeking details to provide to MCC administrators. The complaints centered on the limited availability of visiting rooms and concerns about equitable access for other attorneys with SHU inmates.

An email conversation discusses the potential sharing of information regarding an Austrian passport allegedly held by Jeffrey Epstein, initiated by an individual associated with “USANYS” and forwarded to “[REDACTED]”. The Austrian Embassy contacted the sender requesting information about the passport. The sender offered availability for a discussion on July 22nd or July 23rd.

On July 23, 2019, at approximately 1:27 AM, an inmate, Jeffrey Epstein (#76318-054), attempted suicide in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. He was found with a t-shirt and boxers, a red neck, and snoring heavily. He exhibited erratic behavior, including attempting to fall headfirst and reacting strongly to staff observation. A cellmate, also named Epstein, reported that his cellmate had been harassing him and attempting to kill him, informing his attorney. During questioning, the second inmate stated he was asleep and saw the first inmate with a string around his neck. Examination revealed a circular erythema at the base of the neck and a small erythema on his left knee. No immediate medical treatment was provided due to lack of medical staff availability.

On July 24, 2019, a CAPT in the U.S. Public Health Service, Chief Pharmacist at MCC New York, discussed an inmate’s lack of docusate sodium (Colace) medication. The inmate was on Psychological Observation and hadn’t received a 30-day supply filled on July 12th. The CAPT offered to contact the Duty PA to ensure medication delivery and inquired about the medication’s availability. The communication included standard security disclaimers regarding sensitive information.

Epstein’s case. *   The meeting location is being discussed, with initial preference for Mhotel, but a shift towards potentially meeting at one of the sender’s offices. *   One party is considering a third victim and discussing a potential meeting in New York in August. *   There are concerns about seating availability at the court and a request for someone to secure a seat for the sender. *   A discussion about alternative meeting times is taking place, with the sender open to a later time due to a previously scheduled appointment. *   Confirmation is sought regarding Mr. Epstein’s attendance at the conference.

Attorney regarding a case involving a subpoena issued to Alan Ross, Nascimento’s former partner. The initial contact comes from the Assistant U.S. Attorney who needs to get up to speed on the case after Ross’s passing. Nascimento initially suggests a meeting on Tuesday due to his schedule and the Assistant U.S. Attorney proposes a call, with subsequent follow-up attempts to coordinate a meeting, primarily focusing on scheduling availability for a call or meeting in Florida, especially avoiding conflicts with summer vacations. There are multiple attempts to determine a suitable time and location for discussion, primarily centered around a meeting at the Hilton in West Palm Beach.

On August 6, 2019, a Supervisory Staff Attorney at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York received a complaint from Jeffrey Epstein’s attorneys, Mariel Colon Miro, Esq., and Michael Lambert regarding Epstein’s conditions within the facility. Epstein reported a lack of toilet paper, an un-plugged CPAP machine, and only two fifteen-minute phone calls made via speakerphone with officers present. The attorney requested confirmation of toilet paper availability and CPAP functionality, as well as verification of his phone account setup for ITS calls after 30 days.

An email announces limited availability of the sender from August 5th to August 9th due to being out of the office. An acting replacement is designated for those dates, reachable via phone and radio track 4. The email then details volunteer sign-ups for custody posts on August 10th and 11th, listing specific shifts and locations for Non-Custody staff. The Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York provides contact information including the address and phone number.

This document pertains to a Suicide Watch/Psych Observation case, EFTA00036523, initiated on August 7, 2019. It includes updates on “None” for both Suicide Watch and Psych Observation, and notes the pending availability of SHU beds.

On August 8, 2019, multiple individuals (identified as USANYS) discussed a call with the SEC regarding an inquiry related to the Epstein case. The goal was to avoid providing information that could be problematic for a criminal investigation. Availability for a call was being coordinated among the group, with a proposed time of 4:45 PM.

On August 8, 2019, individuals at "USANYS" coordinated a call with the SEC regarding their Epstein inquiry, aiming to avoid issues for a criminal case.  The call was scheduled for approximately 4:45 PM, with potential availability earlier in the afternoon.  Multiple participants, including "[REDACTED]" and "MM (USANYS)," were involved in the communication.

On August 8, 2019, an FBI agent (Squad C-20, Crimes Against Children/Human Trafficking, FBI New York) requested additional manpower to accompany a team to St. Thomas for a search related to Jeffrey Epstein’s island. The request covered the period from August 11th to 14th. Another FBI agent responded, indicating unavailability due to prior commitments, but offered to potentially reschedule or arrange coverage for a DC trip.

An email chain discusses finalizing an individual's availability for a proffer with the Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, likely related to a case involving travel to Florida. The proffer is scheduled for late next week and is being coordinated with the individual’s attorney. A follow-up call is arranged for approximately 30 minutes later.

An email chain discusses a phone call made by Jeffrey Epstein. The initial email indicates a plan to contact someone regarding Epstein’s availability. A subsequent email from [REDACTED] reports that the Warden of the facility briefed the OIG SAC Modano on a 19-minute phone call. The email states Epstein was not in general population and had a supervised legal visit on Friday. A second email referencing EFTA00027264 is also included.

On August 12, 2019, an FBI agent (NY-C19) was requested to conduct interviews with BOP employees regarding the Epstein matter. The agent is seeking assistance from others and will coordinate logistics this morning before assigning tasks.

An FBI agent (NY) offered assistance with interviews related to the Epstein matter, specifically a proffer at 12:45. The agent was requested to conduct interviews with BOP employees and requested confirmation of availability for assistance that morning.

On August 12, 2019, at 8:45 AM, a reconstruction and after-action event took place from 12:45 PM to 1:00 PM. The event was conducted via a conference call (877-465-7975, passcode: 15546123#) and potentially in person at the DIR’s Office. Marla organized the call to discuss the event with attendees, including the RSD (whose availability was uncertain). The event was classified as X-PERSONAL and had a priority of 5.

An Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York is discussing potential counseling needs for victims related to Jeffrey Epstein’s death. Counsel has inquired about availability for crisis or immediate counseling due to the possibility of accusations remaining unvindicated. The attorney offered to provide information to victims and their counsel and to discuss the matter via phone.

An email chain discusses scheduling a meeting to discuss the next steps in the Epstein case. One party proposes meeting before 11:00 or after 2:00 PM tomorrow, August 12, 2019.  Responses confirm availability and express gratitude.  The email originated from USANYS and involved multiple redacted recipients.

On August 12, 2019, multiple individuals exchanged emails regarding a meeting to discuss the "Epstein case." The meeting time was initially proposed as 3:30 PM, then adjusted to 10:00 AM, 5:00 PM (following a call), or between 11:00 AM and 2:00 PM. Offers included a coffee walk and confirmation of availability. The emails were sent between individuals with redacted names and email addresses.

A request was made by the Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York to have Efrain Reyes, a former cellmate of Jeffrey Epstein, participate in a proffer. The proffer was approved for Friday due to Reyes’ lawyer’s availability and the difficulty in securing agent availability for a takeout order related to the ongoing Epstein death investigation.

EFTA00036421 is a communication regarding a graduating ERT T4T class (August 2019) and subsequent FY20 re-certification efforts. Key details include: *   Welcome to the ERT T4T group. *   A request for graduates to schedule re-certification classes starting in January 2020. *   Guidance on CD burner usage – recommending a portable single burner for crime scene photos, noting availability issues and a potential standard being established by AUSPI. *   Instructions for updating the master list with transfer information. *   Contact information for the Recycling Technician and relevant FBI personnel (Intelligence Operations Officer, ERT Lead Instructor).

An email chain discusses a request for someone to be available for the next couple of weeks to assist an individual (“He”) dealing with numerous requests. One email suggests the recipient, “[REDACTED],” be a go-to person. A second email, dated earlier, references ABS and the availability of assistance from NYM.

Martin G. Weinberg emailed Marty, Michael Miller, Reid Weingarten, and Alex regarding a potential civil forfeiture discussion related to the US v. Epstein case. He offered availability at 9:30 AM the following morning and requested a dial-in be circulated.

The document is an email from Party City promoting its products and services, including birthday supplies, holiday decorations, costumes, and decorations. It highlights same-day shipping and pickup options, and offers a variety of party themes. The email also includes standard terms and conditions regarding text message marketing, pricing, and product availability.

A grand jury subpoena issued on August 15, 2019, commands an individual to appear before the United States Grand Jury for the Southern District of New York to testify regarding violations of 18 U.S.C. §§ 371, 1001, and 1519. The subpoena requires the production of all materials relating to Jeffrey Epstein, including text messages, emails, social media communications, documents, and notes, regardless of location. The rider outlines rights and procedures for the individual, including the Fifth Amendment privilege and the availability of legal counsel.

An email chain discusses Special Administrative Measures (SAMs) applied to inmates. SAMs, implemented by the Attorney General, significantly restrict inmate communication and are typically reserved for national security cases. Inmates with SAM status are housed in facilities like 10 South and ADX (Florence). One sender confirms limited availability of SAMs across various USPs and routinely held them at McCreary. Another sender provides updates on a tour and expresses willingness to catch up via phone.

The email chain discusses an “Epstein Draft” and TDY (Temporary Duty Assignment) officers from other locations (specifically, MCC NYM) assisting with overtime (OT) at the Northeast Region. Approximately 15 officers were TDY during a 30-day period, and the OT was largely provided by these additional staff. A question is raised about whether providing this information would demonstrate additional staff availability and alleviate concerns about current staff fatigue. The document includes attachments: TEXT.htm and EFTA00036618.

An email chain discusses scheduling a call to discuss “NM-related Epstein matters.” Offers for the call include: August 19th at 1:30 MT/ 3:30 ET, August 26th, and several dates/times the following week (Tuesday 9:30 MT/ 11:30 ET, Wednesday 9:30 MT/ 11:30 ET or 1:30 MT/ 3:30 ET). The sender, Holland, notes their unavailability next week due to a trial starting August 26th.

Parvin Moyne from Akin Gump is coordinating a presentation and attorney proffer regarding a production of documents related to Epstein’s accounts with Deutsche Bank. The initial proposal is for her and colleagues to provide an overview of the accounts and transactions, aiming to assist the recipient in reviewing the provided records.  Scheduling discussions revolve around a 2-3 hour proffer, potentially in early September (September 5th or 6th) due to availability constraints and the recipient's travel/trial schedule. The recipient initially requested clarification on the proffer format and timing, and Parvin offered flexibility across multiple dates and times.  The attached index is a work in progress.

Parvin Moyne is discussing scheduling a presentation (a “proffer”) regarding the SDNY Production Index.xlsx to a recipient. The proffer would involve attorneys from Akin Gump, DB Legal, and Parvin herself providing an overview of accounts and transactions linked to Jeffrey Epstein. The initial proposal is for a 2-3 hour proffer, potentially in early September (September 5th or 6th), but the recipient wants to determine the format and expected length of the meeting. Parvin offered availability during the week of August 19th and throughout September, pending the recipient's preferred dates and times. The index itself is attached as a work in progress.

Parvin Moyne from Akin Gump is coordinating a proffer regarding the 2019.8.15 SDNY Production Index.xlsx. Initial scheduling discussions began with a proposed time of 10:30 a.m. on Thursday, the 12th, but the recipient preferred alternative dates in early September (September 5th or 6th). The recipient requested clarification on the proffer format, specifically whether it would involve an attorney proffer or meetings with Deutsche Bank personnel, and the anticipated duration. Moyne offered flexibility, suggesting times throughout the week and in September, pending the recipient’s availability and the need to familiarize themselves with the subpoena returns. Attached was the production index itself.

Parvin Moyne is coordinating a proffer regarding the 2019.8.15 SDNY Production Index.xlsx with a recipient who received the index. The recipient requested details on the proffer’s format and timing, suggesting early September due to scheduling constraints. Moyne proposed a 2-3 hour attorney proffer involving herself, Akin Gump, and DB Legal personnel, offering availability throughout the week and in September to accommodate the recipient’s schedule. The proffer’s goal was to assist the recipient in reviewing the production documents.

An email chain discusses coordinating victim interviews related to a case against Jeffrey Epstein (19 Cr. 490 (RMB)). One individual ([REDACTED]) seeks guidance on utilizing USAO funds to transport witnesses for grand jury, pretrial, trial, and pre-G.I. proceedings. Colleen Mullen confirms a witness’s continued interest in speaking and availability for an interview on August 26, 2019, requesting logistical support (flights/hotel) and information on counseling resources. The email contains a standard disclaimer regarding confidential information.

A communication chain discusses coordinating victim interviews related to the Jeffrey Epstein investigation (19 Cr. 490 (RMB)) within the Southern District of New York (SDNY). One individual requests clarification on utilizing resources for witness travel and subpoenas. Another individual confirms a potential witness’s availability for an interview on August 26, 2019, and inquires about travel and counseling resources. The message emphasizes the confidential nature of the communication and prohibits unauthorized use.

On August 28, 2019, an FBI agent (identified as NY/FBI) contacted another FBI agent (NY/FBI) to schedule a call regarding a briefing with VSD and Jeffrey Epstein. The initial contact involved a request to determine availability for an afternoon call the following day.

An email chain discusses scheduling a follow-up call regarding Epstein’s conduct and property in New Mexico. Proposed dates and times include September 12th at 1:30 MT / 3:30 ET, September 4th (tomorrow morning or Friday after 12pm MT / 2pm ET), and August 17th (availability for colleagues to chat). One party indicates unavailability due to a trial starting August 26th. Redactions obscure sender and recipient identities.

*   New Mexico state authorities are investigating activity related to the Epstein property at Zorro Ranch, including a criminal investigation coordinated with the SDNY. *   The New Mexico Land Commissioner revoked leases held by Cypress Inc. *   The Attorney General is investigating potential criminal activity on the trust land. *   There was a scheduling discussion regarding a follow-up call between parties related to the Epstein matter, with proposed dates being September 12th and September 9th/10th. *   One individual has a trial commencing August 26th, impacting their availability next week.

Nascimento, Esq., of Ross Amsel Raben Nascimento, PLLC, is coordinating meetings with an Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding a case involving a grand jury subpoena issued to Alan Ross. The initial contact occurred on July 6th, with the U.S. Attorney reaching out to Nascimento due to his prior partnership with Ross and his role as a Florida Bar-appointed inventory attorney. Nascimento proposed a meeting for Tuesday at the Hilton in West Palm Beach, initially suggested for 6:30 PM, but subsequent communication shifted to a tentative meeting at 10:00 AM on Tuesday. Several emails exchanged regarding scheduling availability, with the U.S. Attorney proposing various times and Nascimento responding with his own availability and preferences, accounting for a trial schedule and travel plans. The communication involved several redactions.

An individual from the FBI New York WACMT ([EFTA00037846]) requested assistance in securing a conference room or soft room in Los Angeles for interviews related to the Epstein investigation, scheduled for Wednesday, September 18th, and Thursday, September 19th. The request included coordinating availability with victims and options for recording the interviews (soft room with equipment or a conference room). A colleague ([REDACTED]) responded offering to provide a suitable room and assist with building access.

An individual (Sender) contacted another individual (Recipient) regarding a Netflix series about Jeffrey Epstein. The sender’s friend is the executive producer and wants to conduct backward-looking interviews with office staff. The sender acknowledges the likely negative response but informs the recipient of the project’s progression regardless. The sender offered availability for discussion between specific times.

An email exchange occurred between an Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York and multiple parties regarding scheduling a call to discuss the Epstein case. The initial request was for a call on Thursday afternoon at either 2:30 PM MST or 4:30 PM EST. Subsequent replies confirmed availability after 2 PM MST. A confidentiality notice was included in each email.

An individual contacted another person regarding a Netflix series about Jeffrey Epstein. The series has been in development for 18 months and is set to release in a few months. The individual’s friend, the executive producer, wants to conduct backward-looking interviews with individuals within an office, starting with the recipient of the email. The individual offered availability for discussion between now and noon, or after 6pm tonight, or tomorrow morning or after lunch.

An individual (nursaay, zu.t) contacted another individual ([REDACTED]) regarding a Netflix series about Jeffrey Epstein. The series is in production after 18 months of work and will be released in a few months. The producer wants to potentially interview someone from the office for an interview focusing on past events. The initial contact occurred on September 14, 2019, and offered availability for discussion between now and noon or after 6pm that day, or tomorrow morning or after lunch.

An email chain discusses a Netflix series about Jeffrey Epstein, initiated by a person who previously visited an office. The series is a 4-part production that began 18 months prior and is set to release in a few months. The sender wants to inform the recipient and potentially senior leadership about the project and offers availability for a discussion.

On September 17, 2019, the FBI New York contacted someone regarding a call with Jeffrey Epstein. The FBI inquired about availability at 2:00 or 2:30 PM, and also offered a call after 4:30 PM. The recipient responded that 2:30 PM worked.

On September 21, 2019, an Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York discussed scheduling a meeting with Bruce Barket of Barket Epstein to propose a briefing schedule for the penalty phase of a case (EFTA00021692). The Assistant U.S. Attorney indicated availability next week and mentioned submitting a proposed schedule over the weekend as Learned Counsel, in compliance with ABA Guidelines. Bruce Barket suggested times of 12:00-1:00 or 4:00, and the Assistant U.S. Attorney confirmed those times worked, pending confirmation from the rest of the defense team.

This document consists of email exchanges between attorneys at Winston & Churchill and an Assistant United States Attorney regarding a case (EFTA00025355). The emails primarily concern scheduling a meeting to discuss a case involving potential criminal charges and related investigations, including phone records and witness communications. Key details include proposed meeting times (ranging from August 26th to September 6th), discussions about providing transcripts and information about victims, and concerns regarding threatening communications. The attorneys repeatedly offer flexibility and seek confirmation of the Assistant U.S. Attorney's availability. Redactions obscure specific details within the emails.

On September 23, 2019, a contractor ([REDACTED]) contacted the FBI (NY) to arrange the drop-off of a letter related to the Epstein case. The initial contact involved coordinating a time for the drop-off, with the FBI indicating availability throughout the day. The contractor then followed up on September 20, 2019, proposing a meeting for Monday, September 23rd, but the FBI member was unavailable and suggested rescheduling. A letter from a paralegal specialist at the US Attorney’s Office (Southern District of New York) was also involved in the exchange.

An email chain discusses a proposed schedule for penalty phase pleadings. Bruce Barket (of Barket, Epstein, Kearon, Aldea & LoTurco) initially proposed a schedule to be sent by Tuesday, September 24th. The Assistant U.S. Attorney requested a schedule by October 4th. Barket responded that they would discuss and finalize the schedule after a chat, with availability offered for Thursday afternoon (except 2:45-4:00) and next Friday afternoon. Tonyricco, acting as Learned Counsel, stated he would submit a schedule over the weekend.

This document concerns the discovery process in the US v. Maxwell case, specifically regarding the review of highly confidential evidence related to Jeffrey Epstein’s activities. The US Attorney’s office, represented by an Assistant US Attorney, is facilitating the review of electronic images and physical evidence held by the FBI. Key points include: *   **Types of Evidence:** The FBI possesses three categories of electronic images related to nude/partially nude images: approximately 2,100 electronic images and videos from Epstein’s devices, 3,400 discs from his residences, and 7 hard copy images from the FBI Florida office. *   **Review Access:** The defense team (represented by Laura Menninger of Haddon, Morgan & Foreman) will have access to the electronic files, with Cellebrite software provided for viewing Apple devices. The physical evidence will be reviewed at the FBI’s Bronx warehouse under specific conditions. *   **Logistics:** The warehouse review requires two weeks' notice and is open during business hours. The FBI will provide one laptop for image review and can transport items to 500 Pearl Street. *   **Restrictions:** Duplicates of the obscene electronic images are prohibited, and there are limitations on the number of laptops available.  Electronic media (VHS, cassettes, CDs) are not playable at the warehouse. *   **Timeline & Communication:** The Attorney and defense team are coordinating scheduling for the review, with the FBI anticipating a three-week timeframe for reviewing all electronic media at their Manhattan office.  The defense team is requesting information about the timeline for reviewing the evidence and the availability of an index of physical evidence.

Laura Menninger (Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C.) requests permission to review FBI evidence in the US v. Maxwell case, citing deficiencies in the FBI’s initial proposal. She argues that the proposed viewing arrangement lacks adequate facilities for a thorough review, including access to laptops, and the ability for her client to examine discovery materials like recordings. Specifically, she requests: the transport of physical evidence to 500 Pearl Street with her client’s presence, permission to bring laptops and a camera, provision of equipment to play recordings, segregation of “highly confidential” evidence, and a secure room for client consultation. The FBI responds with a detailed proposal outlining the evidence’s categorization (electronic images from Epstein’s devices, discs, and hard copies), stipulations about accessing electronic files (Cellebrite software), arrangements for the physical evidence’s location at the Bronx warehouse, and conditions for reviewing the evidence. The FBI also addresses concerns about the volume of “highly confidential” images and their handling, proposing a phased approach to reviewing them. Finally, the FBI confirms the availability of a single laptop for reviewing the sensitive images and anticipates providing access to the evidence media within three weeks.

Ghislaine Maxwell's trial in the Southern District of New York has been significantly impacted by the filing of a superseding indictment (S2) which added new charges related to sex trafficking conspiracies dating back to 2004 and identified a fourth victim.  Maxwell initially requested an adjournment of the July 12, 2021 trial date and a renewed bail hearing, initially requesting a 90-day adjournment, but later suggesting a postponement until January 2022 due to unavailability of defense counsel. The court requested written answers from Maxwell's counsel by April 22, 2021, clarifying the specific duration of any adjournment request.
